10 years and I tend to uh you know after one year something has to change for me

said I started in academic machine learning um have always been interested in using
that as a tool to build useful things but I actually learned the product
lesson the hard way so there's a bit of a longer story here but the short version is that I you know left um my
academic position and came to work for a startup and the startup at the time we were building statistical models of
career progressions off of millions of resumés we crawled off the web this was
in 20072 2008 I think so it was uh something that was novel um it was not
you couldn't go on LinkedIn and see that kind of analysis done for you uh it was
obviously something I had a personal need for because I was going through a career crisis myself at the time and
that company ended up failing in nine months and it failed because of two things one is that we built some
beautiful data science models put a UI on them and nobody actually wanted to
use them and the second thing was that everybody thought a website about you
know data about careers was meant for college students but the whole idea here
was that you could say you know okay I'm a lawyer and I don't want to be a lawyer anymore what if people like me go on to
do or you could say I'm a software engineer and I want to be a CEO how do I get there what are the career paths that
other people who have made this transition have taken to get there what are the the stages they go through what
other fields do they EXP floor and college students of course have no data so it actually didn't work for them at
all um so there were some flawed business assumptions some flawed product assumptions and that was a wonderful
lesson um and I learned it thankfully on you know somebody else's company and somebody else's money in that you really
have to build a product that is useful to people which of course sounds so obvious when you say it out loud but it
at least was not obvious to me at the time and so I went from being primarily
interested in the modeling to being primarily interested in building useful
things and have spent quite a bit of time studying um and practicing and trying to figure out how to do that uh
in the intervening years and so I'm curious just to that point how do you look at that now because that's always a
hard thing for companies uh to do it's you know it regardless of the industry
people trying to figure out what their customers want and and their needs and and what do people actually want to use
and are willing to commit to how have you addressed that as you've learned that over the years that could be you
know a whole course um there's a lot to talk about there um but I think the sort
of principles of it are really to clearly identify the problem you're
trying to solve and not rush to like try to get to the question don't rush to the
answer um and then you know figure out the people who you're answering this
question for and figure out what's actually useful to them and this
honestly is a mix of both quantitative analysis and qualitative analysis and
really trying to have empathy for the people who you're trying to build for
and understanding where this fits into their lives which are always you know interesting and chaotic and then it
comes back to what we were actually talking about before where you start to build the simple things that can start to potentially address the problem to
understand if it's even worth investing in the best the best things and so it it
really is a process that sort of merges the practice of product management and
product design with the practice if you're building something that depends on that I would call a data product
which is something that really depends on some sort of data science or machine learning capability to build the core
feature of the product so something like a weather prediction like a you know uh
Google Maps is always my favorite data product um the navigation stuff these products could not exist without the
underlying representation of the data um and so you're really trying to figure out what decisions are people making in
what context how do I get that information to them in that context so they make a better decision how accurate
how good does it have to be for them to first get benefit from it but then
second actually use it you know if your weather predictor is 1% more accurate
than another one that's not a compelling reason for me to use it if the other one's more convenient um so really thinking about
all of that and one of the gaps I see broadly in our practice right now is
that we often have product designers and product managers who are in the position to make the best decisions about the use
of data science machine learning in their products but they don't have necessarily the background the knowledge
the access to that Talent OR tools they're certainly not going to build their own deep learning rig in their
house and then you have on the other hand your data scientists who often are not connected to the customers or to the
ultimate you know people who will benefit from the work they're doing and so I think there's uh in our field of
practice there's actually a lot for us to figure out about not just from a you
know I'm a startup and I want to build something new point of view but really you know from your day-to-day practice
somebody in this field like how do you think about doing this work in the organizational structure you're in I
think it's kind of a mess right now and that's a big opportunity for us so I know you and I have met previously and

that I love teaching and I love talking to people it's why I'm here this morning
um and I also really like sharing opinions that are useful and the company
I founded about six years ago is called Fast Forward labs and you know we met at the fast for lab's office uh a while
back that company was built on the idea of doing independent applied research and sharing is much of it as possible
but it's not the the sharing piece is not exclusive to my work at fast forward Labs it's been a thread through you know
my all of the different data science jobs or or management jobs I've had or
things I've gotten involved in and so I think it's really important in this
field to talk about what we do and what works and more importantly what doesn't
work because the field is so young like people have only been able to get a
degree in data science for maybe four or five years and that still astounds me the fact that
you could have a job with that title has been a thing for about a decade there's a lot for us still to figure out and
that's why I love it by the way it's um it is not a solved problem um and our
technology is also not a solved problem it is really weird so if you look at the
change in capabilities of machine learning technology and how you have to manage using them and investing in them
it is completely different than most technology that folks are familiar with
and yet we tend to shoehorn it into existing structures and processes that come from software engineering and so
when I talk about the stuff I like to work on it for one thing um I'd say it's
a it's a two- directional exchange one is that um I and the teams I've been fortunate enough to work with we try to
have a unique or our own point of you um and we try to be and this is really
something I can't help honestly but deeply pragmatic about what something is
how it works where we think it's useful uh this is really important in Ai and machine learning because there is so
much hype there is so much salesmanship there is so much marketing that is designed to get people who don't
themselves have a deep expertise uh to believe something that's not quite true and because the tech is weird and
changing so quickly it's very easy to believe that stuff and so it's really important if I can say this as a
technologist to have those pragmatic points of view and then share them where
you can because we need to build a consensus in the community around what is possible what isn't the best ways to
approach certain kinds of problems um and we only do that by sharing the other thing I'll say is that I love working in
the data science Community because the more that you succeed the more I succeed
we are not directly competing with each other and for the most part if we're data scientists or we're machine
learning Engineers it's different companies I can help you out I can hear about what you're think you're working
on I can share what I'm working on we can give each other feedback and you know within a a certain ecosystem the
more one company succeeds the more another is likely to as well this is really different than um if you ever
have had the the well I don't want to be unkind but if you've ever hung out with a bunch of uh like hedge fund quants I
live in New York City so occasionally I end up well not anymore but I used to end up at those events these folks talk about the weather and
about sports because they do work in a community where there is a significant competitive Dynamic so I I think that
one of the things I really appreciate is the ability to share and having that actually be supportive for all of us and
then I'll also say it's worth sharing because you will get feedback you will meet people who are interested in the
same things you're interested in and I am an introvert um it is very hard for

it but the things I've been thinking about are trying to observe what's missing so you know one thing that has
come up for me is that you know now that I have all of my meetings in this form through a screen
I've started to forget who I talked to about what um and it's because we're missing at least for me the physical
cues that were tied to the storage of memory so I have a couple of folks that we had a monthly meeting in a diner in
Park Slope and I realized I couldn't now we're doing it on zoom and I couldn't remember what we talked about last
because we didn't have that uh you know the physical cue we were at this table and I had this like diner coffee cup and
the eggs were overdone um I love Diner so I say that with the biggest amount of
affection and so it's trying to say okay I've noticed this is missing how do I create that context so can I use
different Zoom backgrounds for different uh groups of people I'm meeting with can I physically alter the space I'm in
which is always hard in a New York City apartment but at least turn around or try and find another corner to sit in
and uh when it comes to the the work of data science one thing I've noticed is
missing is the casual brainstorming and relationship building and I think these
things are tied together but it's really easy to talk about the work that's clear
but it's almost too easy to get caught up in the details of what's obvious and not to spend the time on what isn't

can show you what I see out rain it's a beautiful sunny day in Brooklyn yeah so
I'm trying to be very thoughtful about that and then thinking about you know as we move into play testing some of our
new stuff um you know how we do that in a way that gives us the same kind of
information that in Prior years you could just get by sitting down next to somebody and watching them try to use

um especially as a person in an organization that doesn't have like a big data science team or something like

but I really have no gauge on are they good or are they not and I'm not like

that a lot you're right in that same area and it it is definitely something
that was an issue before covid too I think this has just exacerbated the pain

and observe you that way you know can I ask you a bunch of questions that seem

many characters Do you have do you always make up new characters and so it's really just trying to develop that
empathy through the means we have access to right now but you know honestly it is
a challenge so I guess at this point you you started to allude to character so it
might be a good moment here to talk about your current work and the current project uh you're doing I know that you
announced on LinkedIn which is uh when I reach back out to you uh about hidden door could you tell us a little bit
about hidden door at this point and yeah I'm happy to you um um I mean hidden door is a a product
for using machine learning and AI as a tool for Creative assistance um
primarily focused on kids and the people who like to tell stories and write with
them um and what I mean by that is that I think the tools of uh NLP and natural
language generation are tremendously powerful but they're primarily useful to
provide the things that are repeated in narrative and to accelerate other human
creative efforts and by that I mean kids are deeply creative but they are not
necessarily familiar yet with things like the standard narrative Arc where you introduce tension um how you manage
conflict and narrative in genre writing they may not understand the things you
get for free in a genre versus the things you have to explain they may have
the spark of an idea but but find that it's actually a lot of work to create the story around it and we believe that
the technical Tools around NLP and language generation are just now
starting to become powerful enough to be supportive tools for that sort of
Storytelling and by the way they're really fun um and I think anyone who
spends time with kids or has kids of their own knows that kids are endlessly
creative and they often demand endless creativity of their parents too like so
many parents I've talked to and it's my own experience as well you know it's like can we tell yet another story about
the wombat who really wants to play basketball um or the grape that rolled down the stairs onto the subway and went
on an adventure and so we're building essentially tools that can be part of
this creative process but there are a couple of things I want to be very clear about about one of which is that I don't
expect the technology itself to be creative the creativity comes from
people and the second is that uh this does not do all of the work for you it's
more of a partner in that uh as you explore and create and play uh it starts
to fill in the structures and the gaps and the descriptions and does it in a way that
is really fun and is actually more like a game than like a homework assignment
and then the last thing I'll say because I know this audience is probably deeply familiar with things like gpt3 and a lot
of the issues with natural language generation Tech is that there is a real
need to build uh structure safety coherence and memory into these systems
before they can be deployed for any human facing application much less one that you're

engineering that we're thinking through right now around how you build those systems such that we're confident

in both senses of the word and the last thing I'll say is that I grew up playing Dungeons and Dragons and a bunch of

have our computer system play the role of a dungeon master in structuring and
guiding a story without being you know deterministic about where it starts or

following since then and at the time the state of practice was essentially that
you pre-generated template sentences it was more like a pre-generated madlib
style thing and then you had a process that would dynamically assemble those sentences and it meant that at the time
the tech was really good for taking quantitative data so something like a
weather report for example um or you know a company's uh quarterly earnings
report or even scores in a sports game and writing an article off of that if
you showed it something that it had not seen before it just did not have the
language and did not have like the sentences just didn't exist to be generated and at the time we built uh at
fast forward loves a um system that would take uh structured data about real estate so a apartments in New York City
we crawled was 60,000 apartment listings and then we built uh a little system
where you could say okay this is a two-bedroom two B right by Central Park it has a doorman and washer dryer and it
